Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example: gurban morin [three horse] ‘three horses’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example: ede nyxed [these comrade.??]

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Detailed comment:
-aar/-tai COM suffix
ali ‘and’
-Sje conjunctional particle added to each head noun
Example:
morin-oor [horse-COM]
morin-toi [horse-COM]
Saazgai ba xireenyyd ‘the crow and the magpies’
alirhan-Sje nerhen-Sje yxer nyden-Sje [red.bilberry-CONJ bluberry-CONJ ?? black.currant-CONJ] ‘(There is) red bilberry as well as blueberry and black currant.’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Comment: only diachronically: man EXCL, biden INCL, now both stems are used indiscriminately

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Example:
ene ‘this’
tere ‘that’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Comment: The allomorphy seems to be phonological

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Comment: there are multiple plural suffixes, and each noun can take one of these
Example: xada [mountain] - xada-nuud [mountain-PL]

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Comment: There are collective markers, but they are not inline with the definition of the feature.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Example:
jaba-xa [go-ACTION] ‘going’
yxe-l [die-ACTION] ‘death’
enee-den [laugh-ACTION] ‘laughter’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Example:
jaba-gSa [go-AGENT]
oro-gSo [enter-AGENT]
yxe-gSe [die-AGENT]
gui-ran [beg-AGENT] ‘beggar’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Example: maaZa-nxai [scratch-RESULT] ‘a scratch’

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Example:
axa-mni [elder.brother-1SG]
mori-mni [horse-1SG] ‘my horse’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
tere xybyyn-ei eZii-aba-tai-n [that boy-GEN mother-father-COM-3SG] ‘with the parents of that boy’
morin-Sni [horse-2SG] ‘your horse’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Comment: verbal nouns take verbal morphology and agree with the subject
Detailed comment: verbal nouns take verbal morphology and agree with the subject

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
mor-i:ji [horse-ACC]
bi bagS-i:ji asaraa-b
[1SG teacher-ACC bring-1SG]
‘I have brought the teacher.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
1SG.NOM bi
1SG.ACC namaji

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Example:
mor-oor [horse-INS]
mori-toi [horse-COM]
morin-hoo [horse-ABL]
xana-da [wall-LOC]

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Example:
ger soo [house within] ‘within the house’
ger doro [house under] ‘under the house’
Sere:n deere [table on] ‘on the table’

Feature: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Example: jaba-na-b [go-PRS-1SG] ‘I go.’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Example: jaba-ba-b [go-PST-1SG] ‘I went.’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Detailed comment:
-uuZa
this form is not mentioned in Sanzeev (1962)
in Sanzeev (1964) this form is called a future participle
Example: jab-u:Za-b [go-FUT-1SG] ‘I will go.’

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Comment: there is an imperfective gerund and a continuos gerund
Example:
jaba-Za bai-ha:r 
[go-IPFV.PTCP be-CONT.PTCP] 
‘while he was walking…’
unSa-Za hu:-na 
[read-IPFV.PTCP sit-PRS] 
‘He sits reading.’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
jaba-na-b [go-PRS-1SG] ‘I go.’
jaba-ba-b
[go-PST-1SG]
‘I went.’
jaba-ba-S
[go-PST-2SG]
‘You went.’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
bi bagS-i:ji asaraa-b
[1SG teacher-ACC bring-1SG]
‘I have brought the teacher.’

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
bi bagS-i:ji asaraa-b
[1SG teacher-ACC bring-1SG]
‘I have brought the teacher.’

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Example: jaba-na-güi-b [go-PRS-NEG-1SG] ‘I don’t go.’

Feature: Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Example:
bai- ‘to stand’ - baigu:l- ‘to erect, to build’
jaba- ‘to walk’ - jabu:l- ‘to make go, to send’
jeXede- ‘to become big’ - jeXedXe- ‘to increase’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example: ala- ‘to kill’ - alalda- ‘to kill each other’

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Comment: there are personal predicative suffixes as well as verbs meaning ‘to be’ and ‘to become’ used in equational phrases
Example:
bi xyby:-nSni-b 
[1SG son-2SG-1SG.PRED] 
‘I am your son.’
emSe bai-na
[physician be-PRS]
‘He is a physician.’

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example: ediZe bolno [eat become] ‘it is possible to eat it’

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: bai ‘to be’ for durative, orXi ‘to throw’ for completive
Example:
jaba-Za bai-haar
[go-IPFV.PTCP be-CONT.PTCP]
‘while he was walking…’

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Detailed comment: it is most probably the same as the attributive copula
Example:
mini: morin xojor bai-na
[1SG horse two be-PRS]
‘I have two horses.’
emSe bai-na
[physician be-PRS]
‘He is a physician.’

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Example:
tere xyn jeree
[that person come]
‘That person has come.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Example:
mod-i:ji sabSa-na
[tree-ACC cut-PRS]
‘He cuts the tree.’

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: Negation is marked on the verb, which appears to be clause-final. It is followed by personal suffixes
Example: jaba-na-güi-b [go-PRS-NEG-1SG] ‘I don’t go.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Example: bü jaba [NEG go] ‘Do not go!’

Feature: Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Comment: declarative: bound morphology; imperative: free-standing particle
Example:
jaba-na-güi-b [go-PRS-NEG-1SG] ‘I don’t go.’
bü jaba [NEG go] ‘Do not go!’

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Detailed comment:
the particle üle is used only with participles, no clausal examples available
the particle -güi can be used as a verbal and as a nominal negator

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Example:
ala- ‘to kill’ - alagda- ‘to be killed’
mündär-tä darag-da-han modon
[hail-DAT crush-PASS-? tree]
‘trees, beaten by the hail’

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Comment: There is a precedent, a successive and a continuous gerund.

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Example: u:- ‘to drink’ - u:lga- ‘to make drink’

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Example:
xaa-xaa ‘wherever’
xezee-xezee ‘whenever’
ende-tende ‘here and there’
xeb-xezee ‘always, whenever’

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Comment: Sanzeev (1962): adj normally do not agree with the noun in number, but some adjectives and adjectives in some contexts do agree with nouns in number; Sanzeev (1953): it is typical for Buriat, but not for other Mongolic languages
Example:
hain-ü:d mori-d
[good-PL horse-PL]
‘good horses’

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Example:
te-de gern-ü:d
[that-PL house-PL]
‘those houses’

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Example:
abaga-dai [uncle-DIM] ‘little uncle’
dyy-dei [younger.brother-DIM] ‘little younger brother’
nuur-mag [pond-DIM] ‘little lake, pond’

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Example:
hain xyn [good person] ‘a good person’
zeerde morin [creem.colored horse] ‘a cream-colored horse’

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Example: xyn bygede [person all]

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Detailed comment: bügede can also be used in distributive function
Example:
xün bügede [person all]
xün büri [person every]

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Example:
mini: morin xojor bai-na
[1SG horse two be-PRS]
‘I have two horses.’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Example:
morin-tai [horse-COM] ‘having a horse’
Xojor-iin daXa-tai
[two-GEN coat-COM]
‘two of them have coats’
äSä müngä-täi hän gü
[Esha money-COM be.PST Q]
‘Did Esha have money?’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Example:
teden jere: bi:
[3PL come Q]
‘Did they come for sure?’
äSä müngätäi hän gü
[Esha money-COM be.PST Q]
‘Did Esha have money?’

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Comment: it can be attached to a verb or be free-standing (in examples in Sanzeev (1962) it is free-standing)
Example:
dorʤo hurgu:liha:n jere:-gü
[Dorzo school come-Q]
‘Did Dorzo come from school?’
äSä müngätäi hän gü
[Esha money-COM be.PST Q]
‘Did Esha have money?’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Detailed comment: they are non-inflectioning and appear as adverbs. They take the verb geXe, which has lost its semantics, to enter syntactic various relationships

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Comment: “The presence of a first person pronoun makes the subject phrase a plural first-person phrase”, the example does not support this statement.
Example:
volooda kaata siima gurbantai sugta (jereebdi)
‘(we have come) together with Volodia, Katia (and) Seema, the three (of them).’
bi Si xojor margaaSa jerexebdi
[1SG 2SG ?? ?? ??]
‘I and you will come tomorrow.’

Feature: Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Example:
bäe bariXa
[body catch]
‘to restrain oneself’

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Detailed comment:
GEN of personal pronouns is formed from the stem, deviating from that used in other cases: bi 1SG.NOM
minii 1SG.GEN
namda 1SG.DAT/LOC

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Detailed comment:
jaa- ‘to do what’
xerge- ‘to act how’
Example: jaa-na [do.what-PRS] ‘What is he doing?’

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Example:
xedii xyn [how.many person] ‘How many people?’
xedii-de jerexebta [how.much-LOC come.2SG] ‘When will you come?’

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Example:
tändä Xän bä
[there who be]
‘Who is there?’
kostüm jügäär aba:bSї
[costume how.much buy:PST:2SG]
‘For how much did you buy the costume?’

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Detailed comment:
VN.FUT=verbal noun of the future, Poppe (1960:61)
VN.PRF=verbal noun of the perfect, Poppe (1960:65)
Example:
yxe-xe xyn [die-VN.FUT person] ‘a man who will die’
yxe-hen xyn [die-VN.PRF person] ‘a dead person’
jamar Syleg unSaabSi terenee unSiiS
[]
‘read the poem which you have read!’ / ‘which poem you have read, read it’

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Example:
mod-i:ji sabSa-na
[tree-ACC cut-PRS]
‘He cuts the tree.’ (definite object)

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Comment: in conditional subordinate clauses the subject is marked by GEN

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Example:
xün [person.NOM]
xün [person.ACC]
modo sabSaa
[tree cut]
‘He cuts trees.’ (indefinite object)

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Example:
mal-ai [cattle-GEN]
zygi:-n [bee-GEN]
tere xübü:n-ei eZii-aba-tai-n [that boy-GEN mother-father-COM-3SG] ‘with the parents of that boy’

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Comment: possessor is marked on the possessee
Example:
morin-Sni [horse-2SG]
morin-i:n [horse-3SG]
morin-tnai [horse-2PL]

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Example:
jere:-b
[come-1SG]
‘I have come.’
bi ende-b
[1SG here-1SG]
‘I am here.’

Feature: Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there tongue root vowel harmony?
Is there an initial velar nasal?
Detailed comment: velar nasal is not phonemic; it appears as an allophone of /n/ before a velar consonant and in word-final position

Feature: Is there an initial r-?
Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Example:
xab xara ‘absolutely black’
Sab Sara ‘absolutely yellow’

Feature: Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Example:
hain xün [good person] ‘a good person’
ze:rde morin [cream.colored horse] ‘a cream-colored horse’

Feature: Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Example:
bi 1SG.NOM
mini: 1SG.GEN
namda 1SG.DAT/LOC

Feature: Are gerunds or adverbial participles used to mark adverbial subordination?
Example: xyyged gol deere oSo-Zo zagaha xaxuulida-ba [?? ?? ?? go.away-GERUND ?? catch-PST] ‘The children, going to the river, caught fish.’

Feature: Are specific non-finite and finite suffixes expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Can 1PL marker be augmented by a collective plural marker?
Example: bidä-ner [1PL-PL]

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as nouns?
Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Are there deranked purpose clauses?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be left implicit when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Is there a voicing distinction in fricatives?
Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?
Is there vowel length distinction?
Example:
tohon ‘fat, butter’ - to:hon ‘dust’
dara ‘press (imperative)’ - da:ra ‘freeze (imperative)’

Feature: Are causative posture verbs derived and static-dynamic verbs basic?
Is there a male/female distinction in the sibling terms from the perspective of the speaker?
Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
ARM: gar
"arm"
HAND: habar
"hand"
baglaa
"hand"
zalaa
"hand"
halaa
"hand"

Feature: Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?
Detailed comment: -nar, other suffixes are distributed according to phonological characteristics of the noun

Feature: Can scalar additive operators (‘even’) also be used in non-scalar contexts (also)?
Is there a reflexive-possessive affix?
Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Example:
mangan xün
[thousand person]
‘one thousand people’
nege xün
[one person]
‘one person’
gurban morin
[three horse]
‘three horses’

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?
Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Detailed comment: indefiniteness is Not mentioned. as a motivation for the distribution of accusative and nominative marked objects, but it is mentioned that objects forming a semantically coherent unit with a verb (‘write a letter’, ‘hunt animals’) take accusative marking

Feature: Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?
Detailed comment:
Poppe (1960:112): relational suffix (appr. GEN) -iin/-ai/-n
Sanzeev (1962): dative or instrumental, but dative is more common
Example:
mündär-tä darag-da-han modon
[hail-DAT crush-PASS-? tree]
‘trees, beaten by the hail’

Feature: Is the subject of an adnominalized clause marked by the genitive case?
Can a passive construction have adversative meaning?

Can numeral precede the noun?
Can numeral follow the noun?
Example: Not mentioned.

Feature: Can demonstrative precede the noun?
Example:
te-de gern-ü:d
[that-PL house-PL]
‘those houses’

Feature: Can demonstrative follow the noun?
Can adnominal possessor precede the possessed noun?
Example:
tere xübü:n-ei eZii-aba-tai-n
[that boy-GEN mother-father-COM-3SG]
‘with the parents of that boy’

Feature: Can adnominal possessor follow the possessed noun?
Example: morin-Sni [horse-2SG] ‘your horse’

Feature: Can adnominal property word precede the noun?
Example:
hain xün [good person] ‘a good person’
ze:rde morin [cream.colored horse] ‘a cream-colored horse’

Feature: Can adnominal property word follow the noun?
Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) precede the noun?
Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) follow the noun?
Example: xün bügede [person all]

Is there labial vowel harmony?

Possible Values: 0: one category missing; 1: POSS-case; 2: case-POSS; 3: both

Feature: Is the pragmatically unmarked order of SV in intransitive clauses?
Is the pragmatically unmarked order of VS in intransitive clauses?
Is there an aspiration distinction in stops?
Comment: “In difference from Mongol proper, the phonetic distinction between the strong and weak stops often involves, even in initial position, the feature of voicing (unvoiced vs. voiced), rather than aspiration (aspirated vs. unaspirated).”
